The VHL allele is associated with the von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) tumor suppressor gene, which plays a critical role in regulating hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) stability. When VHL is mutated or inactivated, HIF1A and ARNT remain active, leading to increased expression of genes involved in angiogenesis and cell proliferation, such as VEGFA, TGFB, and PDGFB. This promotes the formation of new blood vessels and supports tumor growth. The VHL gene's inactivation is most commonly linked to clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC), a type of kidney cancer. Additionally, VHL mutations can contribute to hemangioblastomas in the brain and spinal cord, as well as pheochromocytomas. Therefore, the VHL allele contributes to the development of von Hippel-Lindau syndrome, which is characterized by these cancers and vascular tumors.

\boxed{Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome}

The VHL allele is associated with the von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor gene, which plays a critical role in regulating cell growth and oxygen sensing. When VHL is mutated or inactivated, it disrupts the function of the EMTF complex (composed of VHL, RBX1, ELOC, ELOB, CUL2, and ARNT), leading to the stabilization of hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs), particularly HIF-1α. This results in the overexpression of genes such as VEGFA, CXCL8, GLUT1, and EPO, which promote angiogenesis, inflammation, and erythropoiesis. The cumulative effect of these changes is the development of tumors and vascular anomalies, most notably clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC), which is the most common cancer associated with VHL mutations. Additionally, VHL mutations can lead to hemangioblastomas in the brain and spinal cord, as well as pheochromocytomas. Thus, the VHL allele contributes to the development of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.

\boxed{Clear cell renal cell carcinoma}

The CDKN2A allele is a tumor suppressor gene that regulates the cell cycle by inhibiting cyclin-dependent kinases (CDK4/6) and promoting cell cycle arrest. When CDKN2A is mutated or deleted, it leads to loss of function, allowing uncontrolled cell proliferation. This contributes to various cancers, particularly **retinoblastoma** (RB1 is also involved in this pathway). Additionally, CDKN2A mutations are strongly associated with **non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)** and **melanoma**, as they disrupt the p53 and Rb pathways, leading to unchecked cell division and tumor formation. The loss of CDKN2A function also promotes the activity of E2F transcription factors, which drive cell cycle progression and inhibit apoptosis. Therefore, the biological effect of a loss-of-function CDKN2A allele is the development of **cancer**, particularly **melanoma**, **retinoblastoma**, and **non-small cell lung cancer**.

\boxed{melanoma}
